title: Water flow rate and brook trout phenotypes

content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Brook trout (Salvelinus fontinalis) is a species of fish that lives in freshwater streams. Brook trout are adapted to tolerate wide ranges in several environmental factors, including temperature and water flow. Brook trout are well adapted to water temperatures from near freezing (<math alttext="3 degrees Celsisus" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>) to about <math alttext="18 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>18</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>. A researcher investigated whether the phenotypes of the brook trout are affected by the rate of water flow. The researcher collected a random sample of <math alttext="5,000" overflow="scroll"><mn>5,000</mn></math> brook trout eggs and incubated the eggs until the embryos matured. Four weeks after hatching, the juvenile fish were randomly divided into two groups of equal numbers. One group was placed in tanks that simulated a freshwater stream with slowly moving water. The other group was placed in tanks that simulated a freshwater stream with rapidly moving water. After <math alttext="16" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn></math> weeks, the researcher collected the fish from the tanks and measured several phenotypic traits (Figure 1). Some of the researcher’s measurements are shown in Table 1. Figure 1. Phenotypic traits of the brook trout measured under different water flow rates TABLE 1. MEASUREMENTS OF PHENOTYPIC TRAITS OF THE JUVENILE FISH Phenotypic Trait Juvenile Fish in Slowly Moving Water<math alttext="(in millimeters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>mm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>; mean <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar)" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> Juvenile Fish in Rapidly Moving Water<math alttext="(in millimeters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>mm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>; mean <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar)" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> Length of head <math alttext="20.95 plus or minus 0.20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.95</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="20.96 plus or minus 0.20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.96</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Length of fin <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="15.83 plus or minus 0.70" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15.83</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="14.98 plus or minus 0.78" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14.98</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.78</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Height of fin <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="18.08 plus or minus 0.64" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18.08</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.64</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="19.62 plus or minus 0.34" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>19.62</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.34</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) Brook trout that live in bodies of freshwater with surface temperatures that reach freezing (<math alttext="0 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0°C</mtext></math>) can survive in the water under sheets of ice. Describe a property of water that allows the ice to float.

Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Brook trout (Salvelinus fontinalis) is a species of fish that lives in freshwater streams. Brook trout are adapted to tolerate wide ranges in several environmental factors, including temperature and water flow. Brook trout are well adapted to water temperatures from near freezing (<math alttext="3 degrees Celsisus" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>) to about <math alttext="18 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>18</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>. A researcher investigated whether the phenotypes of the brook trout are affected by the rate of water flow. The researcher collected a random sample of <math alttext="5,000" overflow="scroll"><mn>5,000</mn></math> brook trout eggs and incubated the eggs until the embryos matured. Four weeks after hatching, the juvenile fish were randomly divided into two groups of equal numbers. One group was placed in tanks that simulated a freshwater stream with slowly moving water. The other group was placed in tanks that simulated a freshwater stream with rapidly moving water. After <math alttext="16" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn></math> weeks, the researcher collected the fish from the tanks and measured several phenotypic traits (Figure 1). Some of the researcher’s measurements are shown in Table 1. Figure 1. Phenotypic traits of the brook trout measured under different water flow rates TABLE 1. MEASUREMENTS OF PHENOTYPIC TRAITS OF THE JUVENILE FISH Phenotypic Trait Juvenile Fish in Slowly Moving Water<math alttext="(in millimeters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>mm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>; mean <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar)" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> Juvenile Fish in Rapidly Moving Water<math alttext="(in millimeters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>mm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>; mean <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar)" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> Length of head <math alttext="20.95 plus or minus 0.20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.95</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="20.96 plus or minus 0.20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.96</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Length of fin <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="15.83 plus or minus 0.70" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15.83</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="14.98 plus or minus 0.78" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14.98</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.78</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Height of fin <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="18.08 plus or minus 0.64" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18.08</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.64</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="19.62 plus or minus 0.34" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>19.62</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.34</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) Brook trout that live in bodies of freshwater with surface temperatures that reach freezing (<math alttext="0 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0°C</mtext></math>) can survive in the water under sheets of ice. Describe a property of water that allows the ice to float.

(b) Using the template in the space provided for your response, construct an appropriately labeled graph that represents the data shown in Table 1. Based on the data, determine whether there is a statistical difference in the length of fin <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> between the groups of fish in slowly moving water and rapidly moving water.

(c) Based on the data, describe the effect of the rate of water flow on head length and the height of fin <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) In a follow-up experiment, the researcher collects fertilized eggs produced by fish raised in a tank with rapidly moving water and places the eggs into a tank with slowly moving water. The researcher measures the phenotypic traits when the offspring reach the same age as the fish measured in the original experiment. Assuming no natural selection occurred over the course of the experiments, predict the phenotypes of the offspring in comparison with the phenotypes of their parents. Explain how the results of the original experiment provide evidence of phenotypic plasticity.

topic.text: 1.1: Structure of Water and Hydrogen Bonding
